message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of irritability, loss of appetite, fatigue, and social withdrawal, which are consistent with major depressive disorder. Substance abuse is not the most likely diagnosis, as the patient has only tried alcohol twice at a party last year and there is no other indication of substance abuse. The symptoms are not consistent with an adjustment disorder, as they have persisted for three weeks. The lack of improvement over time suggests persistent depressive disorder is less likely as a diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has several symptoms of depression, including extreme irritability, fatigue, loss of appetite, withdrawal from activities, and academic decline. These symptoms have persisted for more than two weeks, which suggests major depressive disorder as the most likely diagnosis. Substance abuse is not supported by the patient history or physical examination. Adjustment disorder with depressed mood would not explain the duration and severity of the symptoms. Persistent depressive disorder requires symptoms to persist for at least two years.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms consistent with Major depressive disorder, including loss of appetite, irritability, fatigue, and difficulty concentrating. The recent loss of his grandfather may be contributing to the onset of depression. There is no mention of substance abuse, and the duration and severity of symptoms are not consistent with adjustment disorder or persistent depressive disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of extreme irritability, loss of appetite, fatigue, and disrupted sleep. The recent loss of a loved one, change in behavior, and academic difficulties suggest the most likely diagnosis is Major depressive disorder. Substance abuse is unlikely given the limited history of alcohol use. The symptoms are not limited to an adjustment disorder, as they are ongoing for several weeks. The symptoms are not chronic enough to suggest Persistent depressive disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest major depressive disorder, including loss of appetite, extreme irritability, fatigue, and loss of interest in previously enjoyed activities. The patient also reports failing an exam and having difficulty focusing, which are common symptoms of depression. Substance abuse, adjustment disorder with depressed mood, and persistent depressive disorder are less likely diagnoses based on the provided information.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest major depressive disorder, including irritability, fatigue, loss of appetite, sleep disturbance, decreased interest in previously enjoyed activities and impaired academic performance. Substance abuse can have similar symptoms but it is less likely given that the patient reports only trying alcohol twice a year ago. Adjustment disorder with depressed mood is also a possibility, but the symptoms have persisted for 3 weeks which is longer than the typical 6-month duration for adjustment disorder. Persistent depressive disorder is characterized by chronic depressive symptoms, which may have been present earlier in the patient’s life. The recent onset of symptoms make major depressive disorder the most likely diagnosis.

We refer to sources on clinical psychology for help. The symptoms are indicative of major depressive disorder, which includes irritable mood, fatigue, loss of interest in activities, and sleep disturbance. The recent death of a family member and the adolescent’s withdrawal from social activities also support this diagnosis. Substance abuse can cause irritability and mood changes but is less likely given the limited history of alcohol use. Adjustment disorder with depressed mood may be a possibility but does not have the same duration of symptoms as major depressive disorder. Persistent depressive disorder requires symptoms lasting for at least two years, which is not present in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms of extreme irritability, fatigue, loss of appetite, social withdrawal, sleep disturbance, decreased academic performance, and limited affect are consistent with major depressive disorder. Substance abuse and adjustment disorder do not fully capture the patient's symptoms, while persistent depressive disorder requires symptoms to persist for at least two years, which is not the case here.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has persistent sadness and loss of interest, which are key symptoms of major depressive disorder. The recent loss of a loved one also increases the likelihood of this diagnosis. Substance abuse may play a role, but it is not the primary diagnosis. Adjustment disorder with depressed mood is a possibility, but the duration of symptoms and impact on social and academic functioning make major depressive disorder more likely. Persistent depressive disorder typically has a longer duration of symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has lost interest in activities he previously enjoyed, has difficulty concentrating and has changes in mood and behavior, which are all symptoms of major depressive disorder. Substance abuse and adjustment disorder may cause certain symptoms, but not to the extent of major depression disorder. Persistent depressive disorder is characterized by a more chronic but less severe intensity of depressive symptoms, which is not consistent with this case.
